question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
One common function where \(\lim_{x \to 0}f(x)\) doesn’t exist is the rational function \(f(x) = \frac{1}{x}\). The same is true for its negative, \(g(x) = -\frac{1}{x}\). Both have a limit of \(\infty\) or \(-\infty\) at 0.

However, when these two functions are added together, we get:

\(\lim_{x \to 0} \frac1x + (-\frac1x) = \lim_{x \to 0} 0 = 0\)

Which is a perfectly satisfactory limit. Thus, these two functions are a counterexample to this statement, proving it false.

To see an interactive illustration of this solution, see this page.

Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

If \(\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow0}f(x)\) does not exist and \(\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow0}g(x)\) does not exist, then \(\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow0}\left(f(x)+g(x)\right)\) does not exist.
